text: Hey there. Um, I'm Wallace Waynehouse
from Epic Games and I am a product
specialist for Reality Scan Desktop. And
I'm Elliot Round, the co-founder and CTO
of MXR and we build measured PBR
technology.
So these are some of the results that
Wallace has been capturing more recently
using Maro and reality capture together
rendered in Unreal.
So uh what is this talk about? Um, it's
basically about making PBR textures and
how to make scans look real. Um, and
that involves making materials that
behave correctly according to light. And
if you have any experience of making
PBRs, you might know that that can
involve using extremely expensive rigs
um um with special hardware, special
expertise and or just a lot of artistic
guesswork.
So before we go into the workflow,
probably best to start off with what are
materials.
So in 3D you have your mesh, but the
engine needs to understand how best to
render that mesh. And this is where
shaders and materials come into play. So
to render a pixel, the engine has to
know does a ray of light pass through?
Does a ray of light bounce off the
surface? Does a ray of light reflect?
Can it have emission? And we use
materials to create a whole wealth of
different styles. So some of these could
be fictitious, they could be fantasy,
cartoons. Um you can do all kinds of
different things, but today we're going
to be talking about PBR, which is a sort
of umbrella of material types.
So this is a scene that we put together
lots of 3D scans. They're all real
objects. Um but at the moment, none of
these have PBR properties. So we have
the shape, we've got lighting, we've got
some simple shading.
But they all look like they all look
very flat. They all look like they're
made out of clay. You don't really get a
sense of what each object is made from.
But as soon as we add the PBR properties
into the mix, they start interacting
with light. They start to look a lot
more realistic and things come to life.
So comparing the two, we can see, you
know, what things are made out of metal,
what things are leather. We can almost
get a sense of a degree of tactility.
Um, and they give things a sort of
grounding within the scene.
And something that I find really cool
about PBR is just how well you can
almost feel the objects. So on one of
these clips, we have this metal tin.
It's black, but in the PBR version, we
can see this is a painted enamel. It's
quite old. It's quite flaky, and you can
almost imagine what it would feel like
to run your hand across the surface.
So the way that PBR does this, PBR
stands for physically based rendering
and it's simulating the sort of rules of
reality. So simulating how real rays of
light interact with the surface of a 3D
object and ensure a degree of energy
conservation. So when you have a 3D
object and you place it into your scene
and you have accurate lighting, the
object will reflect that lighting
correctly. Um it won't bounce more light
off than the light that hits the object
itself.
And if you mix this in with things like
HDRIs, which are lighting environments
that have been captured from the real
world, then these objects look even more
grounded in sort of virtual environment,
and we can almost tell what they're made
from and and feel what they're made from
as well.
So, what makes up a PBR object? Well,
there's two kind of key shaders under
the umbrella of PBR. You have a specular
workflow and you have metallic workflow.
You could argue that they're both sort
of doing the same thing but optimized in
different ways. Today we're going to go
through the specular workflow shader. So
the first thing that we have here is our
base mesh. It's quite low poly. It's
rather smooth and it doesn't have any
complex shading.
When we add normals into the mix,
normals describe what's happening
between the vertices. So it adds a
little bit of micro detail that we don't
have to describe as a high poly mesh.
And when we turn that on, we can start
to see all the sort of scuffs and
scratches and the little kind of flicks
of paint coming off of this old petrol
can.
Now, our first sort of true PVR property
that we have is roughness. So, roughness
denotes when a ray of light hits the
surface of an object, does that ray of
light scatter or does that ray of light
reflect in a sort of smooth line? And
when it scatters, it's very rough. We
denote this with a white value. And when
it's smooth, we denote this with a black
value. So with this sort of old rusty
petrol cam, we can see that the rusty
areas are white and the painted areas
that are quite smooth more of a black.
Um, and then we can also see these thin
white strips which are all the
scratches.
And then we when we apply that to the 3D
object, we can see which areas are
reflective and which areas are not.
The other chop property we have is
specular. So specular relates to of the
light that hits the object, how much of
that light is reflected, how much of
that energy is actually absorbed. And a
lot of the specular reflection does tend
to have a slight color to it. So you see
this a lot with sort of paints, metals
like gold and brass where the specular
reflection isn't white. It might be more
of an orange or a yellow. When when you
turn that on, you start to see the real
difference between the highly reflective
areas like the paint and the not so
reflective areas like the rust. And then
finally, we have the diffuse value. So
the diffuse is our base color. And this
gives it the the main appearance. You
mix that in and you've got your final 3D
asset. And it looks pretty realistic.
Here's another video rendered in Unreal.
in a quick scene, by the way. But that
that object was done in Maro with
Reality Capture. And see with a normal
map, you get like really fine details on
the surface.
And that's a different petrol can to the
one we're actually going to show you
today because me and Elliot have both
got petrol cans that we scan in our
garages.
So, you might be wondering, um, why
aren't PBR scans everywhere? And the
answer is that they're actually not
particularly easy to make. Um, with
normal photoggramometry, the way you get
a texture is you just get a diffuse.
It's a sort of attempt at an albido
texture. And essentially it's made by
just projecting and and mixing every
single camera onto the surface and
blending them all together. So you don't
get any of that material information um
about the reflections and and roughness.
Um so traditionally here's two of the
main ways people might try and make a
PBR material. There's a third one I'll
go into later um by hand um which we'll
go into in a sec. and also using very
very complicated hardware um with cross
polarization and phototric stereo.
So the manual way is kind of like an
educated guess. What people will do is
they'll take the diffuse map. A lot of
you might have had a go at this and then
when you have an understanding of what
what the roughness is going to be. So
basically the darker parts are shinier
and the uh the the lighter parts are
rougher. Um, so in this case, you know,
I made the decision that I wanted the
the grooves in those tiles to be
rougher. Um, so I inverted it and then
messed around with it a bit and got a
sort of vague roughness map there. It's
kind of arbitrary. Um, the bump map I
think I've made a little bit dark there,
but essentially um, you know, the darker
parts sink further away. So I've got the
sort of grooves in the in the tiles
there. And then you can combine it
together and and it definitely looks a
lot more realistic than not doing
anything at all.
Um now here we get into the far more
complicated ways. Um and one way you can
have a go at making a roughness is using
cross um polarization where you use two
polarized filters. Um one in one
orientation on the flash and one in um
at 90° to it on the lens. And what that
does is it it blocks out all the glare.
Now imagine if you do that from every
single camera position and you have a
sort of like glare map from every
picture and then you can blend them all
together and you get like a glossiness
map and then if you invert it um it's
going to be akin to a roughness map. Um
but you can see that it doesn't work
perfectly every time. You can see I've
got that white enamel badge on there and
you can see in the glossiness map that
kind of should be white because it it
should be glossy but it's actually
turned out black so it's got that um
completely wrong. So yeah, it doesn't
work all the time, but um you can get
amazing results like this. And then if
you want to get a normal map, there's an
old technique called phototric stereo,
but it's an absolute pain in the ass to
do. Oh, I've lost my mic. Um because you
need to take an image from the same
camera position with with several
different lights and then the math will
figure out a normal map from that. So
you can imagine that when you're trying
to make a PBR material like this, you
end up with terabytes of data and it's
not actually that easy to process
either.
Uh this is a third one I was going to
talk about. And basically this is easy
because you just take your diffuse and
you just click give me my materials. Um
but it's kind of flawed and you're going
to get really really mixed results and
also it doesn't work on 3D. Um, these
maps look nice, but actually when you
put them together, it didn't actually
look as good as the one that I just
messed around with with the the diffuse
for.
So, we're going to show you how you can
capture 3D PBR using Maro Measure and
Reality Scan all by yourself using
available hardware. Before we do so, I'm
quite interested to get a show of hands
who has the camera and who also has a
flash. So, like a point light or a ring
flash.
Okay, quite quite a few of you. So using
Maro, you'll be able to do just this.
You'll be able to capture full PBR
objects. So we built Maro really as a
way to try and bring PBR to as many
creators as possible. So previously PBR
capture has been incredibly tricky or
using very expensive hardware. It's been
limited to large game and film studios.
So we've come up with a method where you
don't need any complex hardware. So, no
cross polarization, no fancy rigs, no
filters and triggers. All you need is a
camera and a point light. So, this could
come in many different variants. It
could be a DSLR with a little point
light on top. Could be a ring flash.
Could even be your smartphone with the
light within it. And this means that it
could be a AAA game studio, an indie
studio, hobbyist,
student, or even just someone that likes
doing 3D scans. and you can all capture
PBR properties to the same level.
And by simplifying this to just a camera
and a flash, it also acts as a standard
for capture. So if you're capturing
assets from different locations
um through different vendors, you can
bring all of these assets into the same
scene and they'll look identical.
So we do this with flash photography and
this is done by measuring how a 3D
object interacts with light. So we
measure the PBR properties. Based off of
this reflection, by measuring how it
bounces off, we can look at the
specularity. We can look at the
roughness and we can also understand the
base color.
We designed Maro for capturing 3D
objects that you want to put into your
larger 3D scenes. So, it's not really
designed for capturing rooms, but
anything that you can get around with
the camera, you can do a full PBR scan.
We've tried this with fashion apparel,
so shoes and handbags, uh, small to
mediumsiz objects for film and games.
So, lots of props. Uh, even the odd
cultural heritage piece where you don't
have to take the artifact out of a
museum. You simply take the glass
cabinet off and take a few pictures. And
we've even captured a few small to
mediumsiz pieces of furniture.
So, what can you expect for a Marsite
measure? So the software itself delivers
the full array of PBR properties for
both a metallic and a specular workflow.
So we give you diffuse, specular,
albido, metallic, roughness, gloss,
index, refraction, and normals. These
can be delivered all the way up from 512
pixels up to 16K.
And these can be delivered as JPEGs,
PGs, and even 32bit EXR files. It works
best uh probably with freehand. A lot of
the the scans that we've done tend to be
with the ring flash, but you can also
use a rig if you put a small LED on the
top and do your scan that way. But to
get the best results, you need to get
good coverage. And you're going to hear
me say this a lot. So, the better you
can get around your 3D object, uh the
likely are the more likely you are to
capture all of those reflections. And if
any of you are sort of photoggramometry
veterans, this is something that you're
probably not used to doing or doing it
in a slightly different way. Uh but if
you want to get a Maro measured scan,
just please follow along and you'll get
a good measured scan out the end.
So Wallace and I over the next few
slides are going to show you actually
how to do one of these. And we're going
to cover setting up your scene, how to
actually capture. So the better quality
your 3D scan source photography is, the
better the result will be out the other
end. We're then going to show you how to
process this through reality scan, how
to process the PBR through Maro, and
then finally bringing it all together
within Unreal Engine.
So those of you out there who are used
to doing photoggramometry, you might
find that this capture method is a bit
different to normal. Now, for one,
you're probably going to end up having
to underexpose things. Now, the reason
for that is Maro needs to be able to get
values like through the whole range of
the brightness of the object. So, those
high those specular highlights, they
can't blow out. Um, they need to be
below one in value. Um, which can
obviously make the rest of the object
pretty dark, but Maro uses roars and
that's like they've got big um color
depth, so you can pull back a lot of
that information. Now, the other thing
we often tell people is don't bother
using shiny objects. Um, but that's kind
of the point here. Often like the most
exciting PBR materials are going to be
of things with with specular highlights
and and some reflections. Now, lots of
images. That's not breaking a rule
because obviously we do encourage people
to take as many photos as they possibly
can because you can always not use them.
Um, but I think you're going to be
surprised how many you need here. It's
it's a lot more than you would need to
get a really nice uh photoggramometry
scan.
So there's four things that you need to
think about when you're doing a Maro
measures scan. The first thing is the
camera. So when you're using the camera,
it has to be a camera that can shoot raw
files. And the reason for this is so
that we can keep as much of that dynamic
range as possible. So all of the
highlights, all of the shadows, uh,
which will often get clipped if you're
using a JPEG.
The other thing is the exposure. We want
to slightly underexpose the image. And
the reason for this is to again maintain
that highlight. If we expose normally,
we're going to clip the highlights and
we're going to expose for the majority
of the 3D scene. And also locking off
your exposure. So a camera that can
shoot um in manual is really important.
Uh if you have the exposure changing
throughout the scan, it's going to
absolutely mess things up. So find your
exposure, lock it off, and then move
forwards with your scan. The other thing
is lighting. So because we're doing a
measured scan and we're measuring the
response to light, the lighting is key.
So what we want to do is get an image
where the ambient lighting is has no
effect on the image. It is entirely
coming from the point of view of the
flash. So if you're using a point light
source, like a continuous light, it's
best to capture this in a really dark
room. If you're using a flash like what
Willis has here, you can usually, you
know, pump it up enough to overpower the
ambient lighting in the room. Coverage.
keep going on about this, but you want
to get enough views of the object. So,
usually we'll do a scan where you
capture it from the kind of a few rings
around the object and then punch in and
get a few of the details. And then
finally, scale. So, this is something
that usually people don't have to worry
about too much when you're doing a 3D
scan, but for a Maro scan, scale is key.
And the reason for this is when you're
doing um a picture with the flash, the
closer you are to the object, the the
quicker that object is going to burn out
and it's going to look really bright.
And as you move further away, the
lighting is going to fall off more
quickly. So there's going to be a
difference in how bright some of the
images are. If we can measure the scale
of the scene, Maro can actually account
for that. So a few ways that we can do
this is either using some markers, which
I think we have here. So markers that
can be put into reality scan where you
know the distance between them. If you
haven't got markers, you can put a ruler
in the scene. Uh alternatively, you can
even just like measure a part of the
object and do it that way.
So when you're getting your exposure,
the easiest way to get this right is to
actually take two pictures. So the first
image you'll take is with the flash
turned off. And ideally, this will be
completely black. If it isn't, you can
tweak your exposure setting accordingly.
And then the second image take with the
flash turned on. And if that second
image looks nice and slightly
underexposed, as you can see here, then
you're good to go.
So what you can see from this point of
view is is that reflected region.
So by capturing this reflection here, we
can understand what the PBR values are.
And we want to get enough images where
we almost cover the whole object in that
specular reflection.
And we picked this object because it's
got quite a few interesting material
properties on it. Mindful it was quite
hard for me to get through uh airport
security on my way here.
Now, when we're doing a scan, we'll
often do a few loops just to make sure
you've got the general shape. But when
you're capturing something quite planer
like this, it's usually good to sort of
scrub left and right, up and down. And
that will just ensure you that you've
got all of the sort of reflective
regions in your data set.
So this is just an example of of what
that looks like. So scrubbing left and
right, you can see if you were to almost
add all those images together, it's like
you're painting the object with light.
So the whole thing becomes covered.
And if you don't take enough pictures,
so this is a sparse scan. What you'll
end up with is regions where you have
got the PBR property and regions where
you haven't. So your roughness pass or
your specular will have sort of peaks
and troughs within it. So, a general
rule of thumb is the shinier the object
is, the more images that you'll want to
take. And the more matte the object is,
you can probably get away with a few
less. And just for example, all the
scans that we've done of this, it's
around I think about 600 to 700. For
things like shoes that are quite matte,
like leather, you can get around get
away with about 300 images.
So, we've done the capture. Now, we can
go through the rest of the process. So,
just top level of the workflow. do your
scan, you process the data initially
through Maro. You then hand that over to
reality capture, reality scan for the um
3D. You then go back to Maro where you
do the PBR predictions and then you can
take both of those elements and bring
them into Unreal Engine.
So the first stage within Maro is
creating a job. So a dialogue will come
up where you can input the name of your
scan and this allows you to come back to
it many times. And from there we can
also say where our raw photography is.
And when we first load in this raw
photography, we can actually change the
brightness of the image. This has
absolutely no effect on the the PBR
predictions that you get out the other
end. It just allows you to have a proxy
file that you can run through reality
scan. So if it's too bright or if it's
too dark, you can make a quick
adjustment here and then export them to
either a JPEG or a EXR file.
So uh when you send your your JPEGs
through or EXRS through to reality uh
scan, uh you have an option to change
the exposure. So as I showed earlier,
you can just let those highlights blow
out at this stage so we can actually get
a better um solve from all of the
cameras. Um, so I'm going to go through
processing in Reality Scan and uh a
slightly more advanced method that you
won't actually need all the time. So
it's going to be very similar to normal
processing in Reality Scan. Aligning,
meshing, scaling, simplifying,
smoothing, uh, unwrap's important, and
then obviously exporting the files that
Maro is going to need to make those PBR
materials. Um, so you're going to
probably be using shiny objects and as I
was saying earlier, um, they're not
great for scanning. So, spec your
highlights cause issues in alignment and
meshing. Now, the reason for that is in
alignment, the way alignment works is it
finds common features on the surface of
the object and then using those, it can
triangulate where the cameras are. So,
in alignment, we figure out where all of
the camera positions are. Now, in
meshing, we assume that we know where
those cameras are, and then we go in on
a pixel by pixel basis, look for similar
pixels in other images, and then figure
out a depth map. So, we have a depth
value for every single pixel on the
object. And then when we have a depth
for every camera, we can we can make a
nice mesh with millions and millions of
triangles. But obviously because we're
looking for similar pixels, if it goes
to look for a similar pixel and there's
a big reflection there, that's going to
create a mess in the meshing as well. So
we have problems in both alignment and
meshing. So how do we help the
alignment? Um markers are really
helpful. I'm not sure why I've used the
circular ones here because um we
actually have the option to generate um
uh April tags as well, which would be a
better option. So imagine those are
April tags and not the circular one.
Circular ones are fine, but April per
tags tend to be a little bit better. And
the other thing we can do is we can put
stuff in the background. You can see on
the stand here, I've put this like
highly textured material. And reality
scan is going to find loads of tie
points in that which will help the
alignment because all it doesn't
actually matter if the object itself is
helping reality scan figure out where
the cameras in are. It can be anything
in the scene. So the markers are going
to help and any highly textured surface
you can put like in and around your
object will help with the alignment as
well.
Now helping in meshing. Now actually if
we look uh oh no yeah I haven't got the
mesh there but actually this mesh turned
out fine. If you'd simplified it and
smoothed it would have been okay. But
sometimes you'll get like massive holes
in your geometry and obviously that's no
no good at all. So what you can do with
meshing is you can actually get some
scanning spray spray your object and
we'll align those images together with
the ones from Maro like the shiny ones.
And we can just use the sprayed um
images for our mesh. So we get super
nice geometry. And then obviously we
only send the images for Maro back to
Maro.
Um so yeah, the markers are going to
help in this situation if you want to
use this sprayed um workflow because
they're going to help because it's not
going to see the same features on the
surface because one set's sprayed and
one set is not. So the markers are going
to be have to be the same in both sets

everything's all aligned together in one

that's meshed using only the sprayed

Um okay so scaling um as we said earlier
uh you can you can set a scale between
the markers but yeah Elliot also pointed
out you can just if you know the
distance between two points on the
object reality scanner also has features
to do that and that's really important
for Maro to actually figure out um you
know how much light's involved because
it needs to know how far the light
traveled from the flash to the object
bounced back hit the sensor and it can't
make any calculations without knowing
that. So scaling super important. You
can't just have an arbitrary scale,
which is what you'll get in reality scan
unless you actually scale it. It's
totally arbitrary. Simplifying and
smoothing. You can see my original uh
mesh here with 69 million triangles.
I've smoothed to 2 million. I think
that's probably overkill as well. Um but
Maro makes a really nice normal map,
very similar to what you'll get with
phototric stereo. So, your actual final
mesh, as long as it doesn't have massive
holes in it, um, and it's smooth and
nice and not too many triangles, Maro is
going to do a nice job with it. Um, it
has to be unwrapped. Um, yeah, because
Maro also needs to have an unwrap to
work with. So, unwrapped to a single
texture. The default in reality scanner
is a single 8K texture, but I don't
think it actually matters what size it
is. It could be 2K, 4K, 8K, or 16K.
Um, and then finally we're going to
export our files to Maro. So main thing
obviously is a mesh and it needs to
obviously be unwrapped as well like I
said earlier. But Maro also has an
option for a mask mesh. So in this
situation, you definitely want one
because the images underneath are going
to be oluded. So when Maro tries to take
measurements for anything near the
bottom of that, if the table's in the
way, it's going to get a completely
wrong measurement because it's looking
at a table and not the actual object. So
if you send the mask in, Maro knows what
is the object and what isn't the object.
Um, we need ST maps as well, so it knows
what to do with the distortion. So it
has a perfect understanding of the
distortion of the object.
Something we can also do at this stage
is if for whatever reason you want to UV

You only have to do this once. So, if

we go all the way up to 16K. You can
